Summary Highly technical with a background in chemistry, various spectroscopies, and manufacturing process development. Highly technical with a background in chemistry, various spectroscopies, and manufacturing process development. Experience PTD Senior Process Engineer Intel Corporation September 2012  –  May 2015  (2 years 9 months) Hillsboro, OR - Developed vital, robust and challenging etch processes for future technologies in collaboration with vendor engineers; worked with tool vendors to successfully deliver a new process in less than two weeks. 
- Sustained a plasma-etch fleet in a 24/7 manufacturing environment for two technology generations in Intel’s Portland Technology Development. 
- Managed infrastructure and documentation as a subject matter expert in sustaining and development practices. 
- Utilized JMP software for analysis and SQL-like database queries; presented development progress data and proposals to focus teams and taskforces. Experience PTD Senior Process Engineer Intel Corporation July 2012  – Present (3 years 2 months) Portland, Oregon Area Senior Process Engineer, working in the Thin Films - FE Metals group in the Portland Technology Development division of Intel. Responsible for materials, process, and manufacturing development activities within that group. Graduate Research Assistant University of Michigan September 2007  –  April 2012  (4 years 8 months) Carried out research in compound III-V semiconductor growth, strained layer heterostructure growth, ion beam and implantation response of the III-V compound semiconductors, ion beam creation of semiconductor nanostructors, and semiconductor thin film characterization. Graduate Student Research Assistant Purdue University August 2005  –  August 2007  (2 years 1 month) West Lafayette, IN Carried out research on lead free solder development, nanoparticle properties and melting, and nanoparticle characterization. Also conducted some additional work with board-level IC packaging materials. Summary Designing, building, and implementing optical systems in order to address looming questions in cellular (and more specifically viral) biology. Specialties:Optical system design, programming, and cell culture work Summary Designing, building, and implementing optical systems in order to address looming questions in cellular (and more specifically viral) biology. Specialties:Optical system design, programming, and cell culture work Designing, building, and implementing optical systems in order to address looming questions in cellular (and more specifically viral) biology. Specialties:Optical system design, programming, and cell culture work Designing, building, and implementing optical systems in order to address looming questions in cellular (and more specifically viral) biology. Specialties:Optical system design, programming, and cell culture work Experience PTD Senior Process Engineer Intel Corporation October 2011  – Present (3 years 11 months) Hillsboro, Oregon Wet chemical etch of silicon wafers. 
Plasma dry etch of silicon wafers. Postdoctoral Scholar NSF Center for Biophotonics June 2011  –  September 2011  (4 months) Sacramento, California Area Operating a structured illumination, deconvolution, spinning disk confocal, and laser tweezers microscope to study HIV-1 cell-cell transmission and liver sinusoidal endothelial cell fenestrations. 
 
Collaborations include siRNA knockdown of neurodegenerative diseases, echoviral 1 uptake, and traumatic brain injury. PhD Candidate in Biophysics UC Davis September 2005  –  June 2011  (5 years 10 months) Laboratory of Dr. Thomas R. Huser, Department of Internal Medicine and Senior Research Scientist at the NSF Center for Biophotonics Science and technology  
 
Operated both a structured illumination microscope (two different versions) and deconvolution microscope to study HIV-1 cell-cell transmission and liver sinusoidal endothelial cell fenestrations. 
 
Two- 3 months research internships in Finland for research on live-cell echovirus 1 uptake in osteosarcoma cells under the NSF Doctoral Dissertation Enhancement Program travel award. 
 
Assembled a multiwavelength spinning disk confocal microscope using fast timing electronics, an acousto-optical tunable filter and NIR laser tweezers (fixed beam and spatial light modulator driven) to study live dynamics of HIV-1 cell-cell transmission. 
 
Organized the laser safety equipment and paperwork as well as regular maintenance and calendar management of three different microscopes. 
 
Developed a duel mode coherent anti-Stokes Raman scattering microscope with time-correlated single photon counting capabilities. 
 
Trained six interns and two graduate students in optics, object-oriented programming & macros, cell culture, and image analysis. 
 
Built several optics labs/setups from scratch. 
 
Successful biological collaborations including (1) calcium wave imaging in embryonic stem cell derived cardiac myocytes with Dr. Ronald Li, (2) autophagocytosis in prostate cancer cells with Hsing-Jien Kung, (3) chemical and mechanical traumatic brain injury in mouse models with Dr. Gene Gurkoff, and (4) siRNA knockdown of neurodegenerative diseases with Dr. Jan Nolta. Undergraduate Internship UC Davis June 2003  –  August 2005  (2 years 3 months) Laboratory of Dr. Stephen Cramer, Department of Applied Science and Engineering and Lawrence Berkeley National Labs 
 
Determining enzyme mechanics though laboratory and synchrotron based spectroscopes complimented with DFT simulations and vibration mode analysis; techniques included IR, FTIR, Resonance Raman, XAS, RIXS, NRVS, and XMCD at the ALS (Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory), APS (Argonne East National Laboratory), and SPring-8 (Japan). 
 
Designed and implemented the research group’s webpage using PHP, Apache, and MySQL. 
 
Assisted in the rebuild of the laboratory infrastructure under Dr. Matthew Smith. Internship Photonics Industries International, Inc September 2004  –  December 2004  (4 months) Built and performed quality control of diode pumped Nd glass harmonic (0.20-40 W fundamental) and tunable Ti:sapphire lasers. Summer Internship UC Davis June 2002  –  September 2002  (4 months) Laboratory of Dr. Case Van Dam, Mechanical and Aeronautical Engineering Department at UC Davis.  
 
Basic analysis of trends in wind turbine designs. PTD Senior Process Engineer Intel Corporation October 2011  – Present (3 years 11 months) Hillsboro, Oregon Wet chemical etch of silicon wafers. 
Plasma dry etch of silicon wafers. PTD Senior Process Engineer Intel Corporation October 2011  – Present (3 years 11 months) Hillsboro, Oregon Wet chemical etch of silicon wafers. 
Plasma dry etch of silicon wafers. Collaborations include siRNA knockdown of neurodegenerative diseases, echoviral 1 uptake, and traumatic brain injury.
